docs.lead_paragraph: Two powerful leaders of teachers' unions stood shoulder to shoulder with State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday and urged the state government to spend more money on schools, but both stopped short of endorsing him in his quest to become governor. The willingness of the union leaders, Sandra Feldman and Randi Weingarten, to appear with Mr. McCall on the campaign trail seemed calculated to send a signal of support for his candidacy without actually tying the fate of union members to his.

headline.main: 2 Labor Chiefs Laud McCall, But Don't Say 'Endorsement'

docs.abstract: United Federation of Teachers president Randi Weingarten and American Federation of Teachers president Sandra Feldman appear with New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall and urge state government to spend more money on schools, but both stop short of endorsing McCall in his quest to be governor; praise McCall for his work on education; Andrew M Cuomo, McCall's rival for Democratic nomination, proposes that businesses get large 10-year tax break for every job they create as way to spur flagging state economy; Gov George E Pataki signs legislation requiring insurance companies to pay for infertility tests and therapies; photo of McCall with lieutenant governor candidate Dennis Mehiel; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: HealthSouth, the nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, surprised investors yesterday by withdrawing its 2002 profit estimate and offering an explanation that some analysts said was incomplete. It said a new Medicare payment limit on outpatient rehabilitation charges could reduce its pretax profit before interest, depreciation, and amortization by $175 million a year, about 13 percent of its projected $1.3 billion of annual pretax earnings.

headline.main: Market Place; HealthSouth Pulls Back Its Forecast, But Wall St. Questions Explanation

docs.abstract: HealthSouth, nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, surprises investors by withdrawing its 2002 profit estimate and offering explanation that some analysts say is incomplete; says new Medicare payment limit on outpatient rehabilitation charges could reduce its pretax profit by $175 million per year, about 13 percent of its projected $1.3 billion of annual pretax earnings; HealthSouth shares plunge $5.26, or 44 percent, to $6.71; two competing chains, Rehabcare Group and US Physical Therapy, are also battered; HealthSouth also announces that it is reviving plans to spin off its surgery centers operations, its most lucrative unit, later this year; chief executive Richard M Scrushy says $175 million is 'worst case' number and could be lower if company increases its portion of nonMedicare patients; says he is stepping down as chief executive to become chief of independent surgery company, but will remain chairman of HealthSouth; Salomon Smith Barney health-care analyst Deborah J Lawson says she is 'absolutely shocked' at size and effect on profits of Medicare reimbursement change; Tom Scully, head of federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, says he is 'just amazed' that HealthSouth did not bring matter directly to him; Scully headed Federation of American Hospitals, which lobbies for HealthSouth in Washington, before taking Medicare post; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. J. Allan Hobson, 69, a Harvard psychiatrist and dream researcher, arrived for an interview, he had a notebook filled with his writings, photographs of his extended family and renderings of his summer house in Italy. ''This will help introduce me,'' Dr. Hobson said. ''I believe you need to get to know about me quickly,'' he added, demonstrating an easy informality and perhaps belying the stereotypes about uptight psychiatrists.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/J. Allan Hobson; A Rebel Psychiatrist Calls Out to His Profession

docs.abstract: Interview with Harvard Universy psychiatrist Dr J Allan Hobson, director of Massachusetts Mental Health Center's Laboratory of Neurophysiology, whose latest book, Out of Its Mind: Psychiatry in Crisis: A Call for Reform, co-written with Jonathan A Leonard, has just been published in paperback; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Cheney Says Nuclear Peril Justifies Attack on Iraq Vice President Dick Cheney presented the administration's most forceful and comprehensive rationale for attacking Iraq, warning that Saddam Hussein would ''fairly soon'' have nuclear weapons. Administration officials said Mr. Cheney's views mirrored those of President Bush, and were part of an ongoing campaign to persuade the allies, Congress and the American public about the administration's plans for what it calls regime change in Iraq. The officials said Mr. Bush is expected to discuss Iraq in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 12. A1 The Defense Department is notifying more than 14,000 reservists that they may be required to extend their duty, a move seen as a contingency for possible action against Iraq. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Newark -- a 15-minute train ride from Manhattan -- is a leading gateway to New York. But this third-oldest major American city has been enjoying a renaissance, and there are several reasons to stay in town. Newark is aggressively fighting to eradicate its reputation for crime; in fact, crime has decreased more than 50 percent in the last six years. In recent years there has also been an influx of businesses, including the IDT Corporation, MBNA and the SBLI USA Mutual Life Insurance Company, which join stalwarts like Verizon, PSE&G, Merrill Lynch and Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield. The city has begun an effort to revitalize its waterfront, with the Faneuil Hall area of Boston and South Street Seaport in Manhattan as models. The F.B.I. will become the first organization to establish a presence there when construction is completed on its new office building.

headline.main: ON THE GROUND: Newark; A Gateway to New York Is Enjoying a Renaissance

docs.abstract: Travel article on Newark, NJ; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Concerned that millions of workers are losing their health insurance coverage at a time when health costs are surging, employers and Congressional leaders say the next great health care debate will be over how to help the uninsured. Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, an influential moderate Democrat, and leaders of the nation's largest pension plans are trying to drum up support for universal health insurance, a proposal that has received little attention, except from labor unions and liberals, since the collapse of the Clintons' health plan.

headline.main: Next Big Health Debate: How to Help Uninsured

docs.abstract: Employers and Congressional leaders, concerned that millions of workers are losing their health insurance coverage at time when health costs are surging, say next great health care debate will be over how to help uninsured; Sen John B Breaux and leaders of nation's largest pension plans are trying to drum up support for universal health insurance, proposal that has received little attention, except from labor unions and liberals, since collapse of Clintons' health plan; House Republican leaders--House Speaker J Dennis Hastert and Rep Dick Armey--have been working on package of less sweeping measures, including tax credits for uninsured, in hopes of defusing issue before Congressional elections this fall; Kate Sullivan, health policy director of US Chamber of Commerce, predicts that issue will heat up next month when Census Bureau announces number of uninsured last year, which may climb above 40 million--from 38.4 million in 2000--and when Kaiser Family Foundation reports latest double-digit increases in health costs; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Unproductive Medicare Bashing'' (editorial, Aug. 20) reveals how, in the guise of Medicare reform, the president and some members of Congress want to dismantle a program that is both popular and successful. But you do not mention the five million people who are eligible for Medicare based on disability. They, too, require a prescription drug benefit that is included in the Medicare program.

headline.main: Medicare Is the Solution for All

docs.abstract: Letter by Vicki Gottlich of Center for Medicare Advocacy charges that Pres Bush and some members of Congress, in guise of Medicare reform, want to dismantle program that is both popular and successful (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST before Wendy Lambke bought her first house, in August 2001, she shopped around for homeowners' insurance. After comparing four or five rates, she ended up buying a policy offered through her alma mater, Iowa State University in Ames. ''It turned out to be the cheapest insurance policy I could get,'' Ms. Lambke said of the $300 premium offered by the Liberty Mutual Group of Boston. So good a deal, in fact, that when it came time to renew her auto insurance, she switched to the plan offered to Iowa State alumni by Liberty Mutual. ''I'm probably saving a few hundred dollars a year,'' she said, or about 20 percent, compared with other plans.

headline.main: Personal Business; Your Alma Mater Wants to Become Your Bank

docs.lead_paragraph: I woke around midnight, threw up and went back to sleep. Nausea was nothing new. I had been throwing up constantly -- sometimes as often as 12 times a day -- throughout my pregnancy, but that night something felt different. If I had had to describe my symptoms right then, I would have resorted to the familiar vocabulary of illness -- I was dizzy, my heart was racing, I felt short of breath. I guess. The truth is, those words felt generic and crude, unequal to the task. What I felt was more elemental, as if my bodily organs -- mysterious, essential things I knew I had but couldn't feel -- had begun to malfunction in some subtle, unspeakable way. For the next few hours I lay on the bathroom floor throwing up, letting the tile cool my body as it shook uncontrollably after each episode, first freezing, then burning. A few hours later I got up, went into the bedroom and lay down next to my husband. I could tell from movement on the other side of the bed that he was awake. ''I'm scared,'' I said out loud.
docs.abstract: Rebecca Johnson article describes her pregnancy and diagnosis of pre-eclampsia; says it affects 7 percent of all pregnant women--usually in mild forms--and is one of leading causes of death among pregnant women worldwide; says there is little consensus about what causes it, how it works and, more important, how to treat it; tells sad outcome in her case: her child, Luke, died shortly after being born; photos (M)
